body.p:
Historical Background
Only some twenty–five years ago, with the discovery and initial excavations in 1087–8 of a
Roman amphitheatre under what is today the citys Guildhall Tard, London was shown to
have been a city with significant public, civic–sponsored entertainments from very close to its
founding by the Romans c 50–2 AD. In the amphitheatres of the Roman Empire, city mag*
istrates routinely provided entertainments on public festive occasions: and Roman Londons
amphitheatre, first built of timber in 70–I aD and then dismantled and rebuilt partly in stone
in the early second century, would probably have been the site of public wild–animal shows,
gladiatorial contests, athletic competitions, and military drills and exhibitions. (By c 120–5 AD
London's Roman military fort was nearby, to the northwest.:) Doubtless the amphitheatre
most recently estimated to have held, at first, around 6, 9O0 spectators, and around 7, O00 to
10, S00 after the structure was rebuilt– hosted other public entertainments as well, such as
mime (variety entertainment) and pantomime (dance drama), if Roman London did not also
have a separate theatre.S Music would have been part of some of these entertainments. It
would have been unusual for a Roman centre as large and important as Londinium not to
have had a theatre as well as an amphitheatre, or perhaps an odeon, but no theatrical structure
other than the amphitheatre has been found by archaeologists to date. Also missing today is
any evidence of the mock naval battles (naumachia) which the Romans enjoyed watching in
other parts of the Empire and for which the Thames at London would have been a convenient
site. Roman London was, however, a flourishing city: one of the major cities of the western
Roman Empire (recently estimated to have had perhaps ten thousand inhabitants by 60 AD
and up to thirty thousand inhabitants by the early second century), an important trading
port, and the centre of Roman roads leading out to other parts of Britain.: It prospered unti
the third century, and we are probably safe in speculating that types of public and private
entertainment common in other western parts of the Empire, both musical and theatrical
would have normally been available in Londonium as well. S
No written evidence of theatrical activities in Roman London, or for over seven hundred years
after the Romans left Britain in A10 AD, has come down to us today. Roman London seems to
have been abandoned by probably the early fifth century, and the Saxon town of Lundenwic
was built in the late seventh century just upstream from what had been the walled Roman
city (although the first St Paul's cathedral church was founded, c 604, within the old walls,
and a royal palace may have been built there as well). From this period on, through London's

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xi1
late–ninth–century re–establishment within the walls by king Alfred,s until the late twelfth
century, we have no material remains or written records indicating anything about theatrical
entertainment specifically in London: and we also do not know about city governance in
much particularity, although a history of the city can be pieced together from a variety of
sources, such as early chronicles, charters, and other legal documents.* It is inconceivable,
however, that Lundenwic and then London – a centre of national and international trade in
the late seventh and early eighth centuries, and a flourishing and wealthy international port
and economic centre at the time of the 1066 Norman Conquest€¢– would have been without
a variety of entertainments and music: indeed that musical activity would have continued in
early London, at this time, has not been questioned. All we know about theatrical performance
in London for this period, however, are generalities: the persistence, in societies throughout
human history, of a love of performance entertainment in general: the persistence also of
entertainers in their profession: the normal continuity therefore of performance traditions
from one generation to the next: the survival, after the Romans, of a knowledge of their
drama through the reading of classical texts among the educated classes: a few surviving
Christian ecclesiastical records of hostility towards ludi (games/plays) and spectaculi in
Britain generally৳ and an Old English and Latin working vocabulary including words for
amphitheatre, theatre, and actors. Christian drama also, as it developed in the tenth to
twelfth centuries, was demonstrably being performed elsewhere in England (for example, in
Winchester from the tenth century), and so is unlikely not to have existed as well in populous
and wealthy London (now back within its walls), with its bishopric of St Paul's, numerous
churches (many founded in the eleventh century), and many religious houses.
By the later twelfth century, we have texts extant of sophisticated religious plays which
though without any specific London connection, show the highly developed state of the
Christian drama at this time in various parts of Europe, including England and France./ A
secular Latin comedy, B$₽€¢, is also extant, possibly a court piece (to be performed or read)
by author/scholar Walter Map, whose patron was Henry 11: but whoever the audience or the
readership was for B$₽€¢, the work is unlikely to have been unique, and plays for the court
and for a London mercantile audience would probably not have differed, given the wealth
and sophistication of London's civic leaders and their interactions with royalty and nobility.
Towards the end of the twelfth century comes our first written evidence of theatrical
activity specifically in London. Some time between c 1170 and 1182, William fitz Stephen,
the London–born, church–educated secretary to Thomas Becket (before Becket's murder in
1170), wrote his now famous Descriptio Londoniae (Description of London), in which
he seems to refer to a thriving religious theatre – as well as other forms of entertainment
in the city৳ and c 1103, Winchester monk Richard of Devizes wrote in his Chronicle about
city secular entertainments. 5 Fitz Stephen, comparing London favourably with ancient Rome,
writes of London's holier plays, on miracles by holy confessors or the sufferings of martyrs,
and even if these (as some historians have suggested) might not have been plays in the modern
sense of the word, fitz Stephen certainly seems to be writing about something theatrical and
significant. He does not mention sponsorship: but such plays seem unlikely to have been
performed by small, independent acting troupes, and could have been organized by one or
more religious institutions or by the city. He also mentions cockfighting, dancing, wrestling,

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xiii
boar–fighting, bull and bear baiting, and other sports and games.S The material in Richard
of Devizes Chronicle is also significant. In a story about a smooth–talking villain attempting
to lure a young man to his death, Richard puts into the villain's mouth warnings about
the iniquities of London, which include the theatrum, along with dice, gambling, and the
tavern, and evildoers, such as jesters, dancers, quacks, magicians, pimps, sorceresses, mimes,
and histriones (actors/entertainers).1 The sinful city was a common trope in medieval liter*
ature: and the villain in the Chronicle is attempting to mislead the young man into going to
Winchester (where he will subsequently be murdered). Nevertheless, the list of locations and
activities (on a factual basis rather than in terms of the moral slant of the narrative) presumably
had some recognizable contemporary applicability to London as a place where one could find
various kinds of (non–religious) entertainment. Richard of Devizes entertainers certainly
were not city–sponsored: but unless his description of activities in London is to be taken as
purely literary, the performers listed would seem to be signs of a thriving secular entertain*
ment business in the late–twelfth–century city, as we might expect given the size, wealth, and
prominence of London under Richard I (1185–00) and then ]ohn (1155–1216).2
Twelfth–century London was indeed a thriving and international mercantile centre, ideally
situated on the Thames at a strategic point that could be reached by ocean–going vessels and
yet where a bridge could also be constructed across the river, with roads running from the
city both north and south, making London the hub of the country's trading and travelling
networks. It was the largest and richest city in Britain,2 and its importance continued to
grow throughout the medieval and early Tudor periods, despite a significant population
reduction at the time of the Black Death.2 Although the monarchy was peripatetic, moving
around the country as it suited each monarch, the wealth, the location, the abundance of
goods both local and international, and the general stability of London served as a magnet foi
royalty, the nobility, and the upper echelons of the clergy. A number of religious institutions
were founded in and around the city during the twelfth century₮€৳ Wealthy aristocrats and
ecclesiastics began by c 1200 to build imposing townhouses in and close to the city, as bases
for carrying out business there, and the palace at Westminster was a royal favourite.2 By
the late twelfth century, the Exchequer had become established at Westminster. By the
mid–fourteenth century, most of the other administrative functions of the Crown had become
located there as well, where the parliament also regularly met, while the Great Wardrobe,
a major provisions department for the court, had been established in London itself.25 Cirty
and court, involved in a relationship of mutual self–interest from very early times, became
increasingly dependent upon one another. The city was a source of money, of manpower,
and of goods for the Crown: the Crown was expected by the city to maintain the political
stability necessary for its mercantile activities to flourish. London's support was essential if
a monarch was to gain or to retain power: but the favour of the monarch was also essential
to London's economy both nationally and internationally. This interdependence of court
and city was cultural as well as economic and political, extending throughout the period
(1287 to 1558) covered by the records in this collection.2
London's privileges of self–government existed, at least in part, from very early times.
From apparently the end of the twelfth century, London was given the right by the Crown to
elect its own mayor annually, although this privilege was not formally set down until king

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xiv
]ohn's 9 May 1215 charter to the city. The chosen individual was, however, required to
swear an oath to the Crown, and from time to time, until the fifteenth century, the king
intervened strongly in the election process or even sometimes took the city into his hand
that is, took it under his direct governance via an appointed warden, in place of the mayor,
when he became displeased with the conduct of the current mayor or of the city government
in general.2 By the fifteenth century, the king still exercised considerable influence over
the election, but diplomatic pressures – although sometimes considerable– had replaced
direct interventions. London also, by 1150–1, chose for itself two sheriffs annually (althougk
the shrievalty had existed for more than a hundred years before that).2 The sheriffs were
answerable to the kings Exchequer barons, and normally served for only one term,8 whereas
the mayor until 1380 might be re–elected for several consecutive years and subsequently
between 1380 and 1424–35, might serve for more than two non–consecutive terms. 21
Gradually, over the years, the shrievalty became less important than the mayoralty, and
in 1385 the citys common council decreed that the office of sheriff was a necessary step
before an individual could reach the mayoralty.€ The city jealously guarded its rights in
relation to the mayoral and shrieval elections, and political changes over the decades and
centuries led to increasingly greater freedom from royal interference. The processions
of the sheriffs and mayor annually to Westminster, however, to be confirmed in office by
the king or by his Exchequer barons, remained throughout this period (that is, to 1558)
important ceremonial occasions involving music and, eventually for the mayor's proces
sion, pageant display.
Under the sheriffs and, by the late twelfth century, the mayor with their various officers
London was divided for governing purposes into wards (around twenty–four by at least
the early twelfth century), each headed by an alderman (a fairly full list is extant from
c 1127) / The aldermen, who held office for life throughout most of the twelfth to sixteenth
centuries, had judicial responsibilities in their wards, were responsible for keeping order in
times of crisis, put civic regulations into effect, collected taxes, presided at the wardmote
and kept ward records.5 As the court of Aldermen, they met about once a week in the early
fifteenth century and about three times a week by the mid–fifteenth century.s London also
had, from at least the fourteenth century, a common council (in part the successor of the city's
original folkmoot) composed of representatives of the wards and responsible for taxation
decisions, often taxation assessments and audits, negotiations with the Crown, civic projects
requiring expenditures, disputes between craft/trade guilds, and regulations concerning the
city's freedom (citizenship)./ The aldermen and the common council cooperated in admin*
istration, and formed joint committees on a number of significant matters (finances, repairs,
etc). 88 Both the aldermen and the common council were involved with civic activities and
decisions in relation to musical and theatrical matters. Various city officers involved with
these activities also appear regularly in the civic manuscripts before 1558 – especially, in the
records transcribed, the chamberlain, common clerk, and recorder. The chamberlain was the
city's chief financial officer, whose office dealt with city income and expenditures. The
common clerk gradually became responsible for the creation and safekeeping of city records
The recorder, who had primarily legal responsibilities, also made formal public speeches of

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xv
welcome to visiting dignitaries, including those who were accorded a pageantic entry through
the city.
In part in return for its considerable political independence, the city served as a cash cow
for the monarchy, frequently taxed to fund royal activities such as wars abroad, and obliged
to provide loans to the king. It was also expected not only to maintain defensive capabilities
in case of need at home but also at times to provide actual manpower for foreign wars.1o
With Westminster as the favoured seat of the monarchy, London was also often called upon
to offer a formal welcome, as well as sometimes lodgings and feasts, and often gifts, to royal
and other important visitors (for example, ambassadors, papal emissaries) to the court from
abroad. It was also expected to escort English monarchs themselves, and sometimes members
of the royal family, on formal passages through the city, going to or from Westminster. Foreigr
monarchs of considerable importance would be accorded especially elaborate welcomes. Also
since coronations of English monarchs from the late eleventh century regularly took place
at Westminster Abbey, London was as well the standard site for the formal pre–coronation
procession, from the Tower of London through the city to Westminster, which was requirec
of the monarch from at least the time of Richard Il: the king was to show himself bare₯headed
to his subjects on the day before his coronation. (Both Edward I and Edward II are also known
to have made a pre–coronation procession through the city, but no document requiring this
has survived for those early years, and the recording chronicles do not specifically mention
the Tower as a starting point.8) Cueen consorts, when crowned later than the king, also made
a pre–coronation procession through London, the earliest described seemingly being that
of Eleanor of Provence in 1236. From at least the late fifteenth century there were standard
requirements set down for this kind of procession as well (including the Tower to Westminster
route), which likely date back to at least 1445.
All of this ceremonial activity required from the city established procedures of welcoming
and of escorting, and often considerable expenditure. Coronation and other such major
entries had particularly elaborate and highly expensive requirements, including constructed
and[or role–playing pageants: and these entries were sometimes well spaced out, but at other
times clustered together. Three coronations, for example, took place, with elaborate entries
in the twelve years between February 1546/7 and [anuary 1558/98, along with a similarly
elaborate royal welcome– for Philip of Spain, the new husband of Oueen Mary– in 1554.
Far more than any other city or town in England, London was called upon to spend atten*
tion, time, and very large sums of money, with comparative frequency, on a full range of
welcoming/honouring occasions – although these occasions, of course, not only honoured
those being welcomed, escorted, or celebrated, but also were a demonstration of the city's
wealth, power, and importance to the Crown. London's nearness to Westminster was both a
source of wealth and independence (through privileges granted by the Crown, through the
purchasing activities of all of the Crown, the aristocracy, and the upper levels of ecclesiastics,
and through the city's demonstration of its power) and a drain on wealth and independence, and
turned the formal receiving of royal and other important personages into an ongoing activity
such as existed nowhere else in England. London probably thus also became a centre, from
very early times, for those who could provide, for the higher level of entries, the components

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xvi
of these kinds of significant musical and theatrical occasions. Meanwhile the fondness of the
court for its own musical and theatrical entertainments, and the close relationships between
the city elite and the court, also made inevitable the existence from very early times of a
flourishing indoor musical and theatrical culture in the great halls of civic London. ]ohn
Lydgate, for example, was commissioned in 1425–30 both by the court and by at least two
city guilds/companies (for which, see below) to produce special hall entertainments for the
fall, winter, and spring of the year of Henry vi's English coronation, which took place in
November 1420.2
For London's civic musical and theatrical activities before 1300, we are largely dependent
on sources other than civic records (see Appendix I), but in 1275/6 the city began its first
ongoing series of written records of city business, the Letter Books, which are extant today.
Beginning largely as registers of bonds and recognizances,88 they soon became the essential
record of the business of the city, as conducted by its mayor, aldermen, and common council,
with important external documents (such as orders from the king) also copied in. The earliest
Letter Books, A through C, have yielded only one record for this edition, but from Letter
Book D on (that is, beginning c 1300), relevant records gradually increase, although largely
from the late fourteenth century into the fifteenth. In 1416 a second manuscript series was
begun, the [ournals, for the recording specifically of the business conducted by the common
council and the court of Aldermen. In 1405 the business of the aldermen was split off into
yet a third series of manuscripts, the Repertories. Significant items from the [ournals, from
1416, and from the Repertories, from 1405, were copied into the Letter Books. For music
and theatre historians today, therefore, as the fifteenth century moves along, the Letter Books
gradually become less important than the ]ournals and the Repertories as original sources of
information. Unfortunately no chamberlain's accounts, which would have been a major source
of information on all city activities and occasions involving receipts and expenditures, have
survived for London before the late sixteenth century, other than a few summaries copied
into the Letter Books in the 1330s and 1340s, and one subsidiary account, for 1535–6,
kept by a chamberlain's clerk.*
In addition to the Letter Books, [ournals, and Repertories, as early civic series of manu*
scripts with information on London's musical and theatrical activities, are two partially
extant accounts series belonging to London Bridge, which was run by the city as a separate
enterprise (essentially a trust). The Bridge House, headed by two elected wardens (or
bridgemasters), was mandated in part to generate income for Bridge maintenance, the key
components of which were tolls and the rentals of Bridge properties both on the Bridge
itself and elsewhere in the city.* The annual accounts of the bridgemasters are partially
extant for 1381–1405 (17 rolls) and 1404–60 (only one rental, and weekly receipts), and
extant in full from 1460 to the end date of this collection: and their detailed series of weekly
payments are extant, up to 1558, for 1404–45, 1505–38, and 1552–5. These records are
important for historians of London theatre and music because, almost invariably before the
last part of the fifteenth century, and occasionally after, major entries into the city involved a
ceremonial crossing of London Bridge, with music and pageantry paid for by the Bridge
itself. In some years in the fifteenth century, detailed costs are included in the extant Bridge

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xvii
House manuscript accounts.* No such payment records have survived – although they must
have originally existed– for pageants provided within the city directly by the civic govern*
ment.৳ The only records, for example, of constructed pageantry for the 1465 coronation
entry of Elizabeth Woodville, queen to Edward Iv, come from the Bridge House manu
scripts, which provide details of the Bridges expenditures on displays and music.2 Edward
1v's marriage was not popular, either at the court or outside it, so possibly there was major
display only at the Bridge: but more likely the pageantry was more extensive and chroniclers
our main source of information today on early royal entries– simply did not report on
the entry because of the absence either of popular interest or of royal pressure. (In 1533
when the unpopular Anne Boleyn made her coronation entry through London, pressure
from Henry viIi led not only to elaborate displays but also probably to the lengthy chronicle
descriptions of them which we now have. 5) The civic rulers spent a considerable amount
of money in 1465 on the decorating of the city, but we have no information on what that
involved.
After 1465 the Bridge House manuscripts tell us little about Bridge pageants and music:
but after 1483 the Bridge House becomes, in any case, a much less important potentia
source of pageant information than before. From 1483, coronation entries through London
increasingly came to involve a water procession to the Tower of London– the starting point
for the mandated pre–coronation procession through the heart of the city– rather than a land
procession from Southwark across the Bridge. Richard IIl, perhaps for reasons of security, went
to the Tower before his coronation by water, and although Henry vil crossed the Bridge, his
consort, Elizabeth of Tork, went to the Tower by barge, with pageantry on the water– for
example, a fire–spouting dragon– instead of the traditional Bridge pageantry. Henry VIII, for
his coronation entry in 1500, crossed the Bridge, but all subsequent sixteenth–century
coronation entrants, except Edward vi, went to the Tower by water. Edward did not process
to the Tower by land or by water: he had remained in the Tower, after his accession, until
his entry through the city the day before his coronation. One–day non–coronation entries
in 1501 by Ratherine of Aragon, coming to marry Prince Arthur (heir to the English throne),
and in 1522 by the visiting emperor Charles V– continued to use the Bridge, but after
1522 no such major non–coronation entries took place for the rest of the sixteenth century.
Unfortunately, even where detailed Bridge House records are extant for the years of the few
major royal entries using the Bridge after 1465, they no longer provide detailed information
on Bridge pageants. Chronicle histories become our main information source.
London's city government– of the mayor, sheriffs, aldermen from the wards, and common
council– was considerably dependent on two other forms of local government in carrying
out its civic functions. One of these was religious government: the territory, in part, of REEDS
E₯₯₮£৳€$৳૱€₯$₮ L¢₭₨¢₭ collection, which deals with the surviving records of the city's parishes,
St Paul's Cathedral, and the diocese of London. The other was the internal government and
authority of each of the various London craft or trade guilds, organizations whose extant
records of pre–1550 music and theatre, some from as early as the fourteenth century, are a
major part of this collection. These guilds were originally formed by particular occupational
groups (for example, bakers, goldsmiths, pewterers, saddlers) for purposes of crast or trade

HISTORICAL BACkGROUND
xviii
regulation, religious worship, and/or mutual social support (they largely included reli.
gious/social fraternities as part of their organizational structure). By the thirteenth to four*
teenth centuries they had become political groups of businessmen, through which a sub–
stantial amount of the city's governing was directly or indirectly carried out. Throughout
this collection, these organizations are called companies, to distinguish them from purely
religious guilds and to be consistent in terminology over a time period during which gradually,
from the fourteenth century on, most of the organized crast or trade guilds surviving from
earlier times acquired royal charters and became what are today called livery companies:
incorporated organizations, able to hold property, whose senior, more substantial members
wore (and still wear today) a distinctive company gown andlor hood (livery) on formal occa*
sions. S Today the surviving companies from the pre–1550 period, along with numerous others
created later, are essentially London private associations involved in charitable work, education,
and social activities, sometimes with links to their original crafts or trades. In early London,
however, although differing from one another to (sometimes widely) varying extents in financial
means, interests, and operation, generally they regulated their crafts and trades, settled their
members disputes, and carried out various religious, social, and charitable responsibilities
These included praying for the souls of departed members, walking or riding (on horseback
or on barges) in procession on specific city religious and secular occasions (such as the mayoral
and shrieval inauguration processions to Westminster), and looking to the welfare of impecuni.
ous members (which could include, for the better–off companies, the establishing of alms–
houses). The companies carried out other important functions as well for the city, such as
providing funds for royal loans and taxes and for routine civic projects and special initiatives
(such as the building of kitchens at the Guildhall in the early sixteenth century). Most
importantly for this collection, all of the companies – at least all of those stable and sufficiently
solvent at any given time – also contributed to the city's formal street music and pageantry.
Especially active in this were the Great Twelve companies, a group of companies wealthier
and more influential than the rest, standing one to twelve in the order of precedence that,
although fluctuating somewhat, from its informal beginnings in the fourteenth on into the
early sixteenth century, ranked all city companies in relation to one another.₺s Like othei
companies, the Great Twelve (known as such by the late fifteenth century) processed frequently
in their livery gowns and hoods, and often with music, with the mayor and other city officials
on various kinds of occasions (such as mayoral and shrieval inaugurations and ridings to
meet entering royalty: the processional responsibility itself was normally included in companies
ordinances). But they also contributed in a major way–at least from the late fifteenth century
to the annual Midsummer Watch, a night–time parade held yearly on the eves to mornings
of 23–4 and 28–0 ]une (see below, pp xxxiv–xl). All of the companies able to do so con–
tributed men to the Watch when required: but it was largely the Great Twelve– from whose
membership by this time came always the mayor and usually the sheriffs– that were responsible
for the constructed portable pageants, morris dancers, giants, fireworks, and the like which
were normally a part of the Watch by at least the early sixteenth century. The companies
with a mayor or a sheriff in office at midsummer in any given year provided the display and
entertainment in that year. Occasionally a sheriff was not from a Great Company, and his
